child.pub-comments: "Caviteño, is the modern descendant of Ternateño, and is still extant, though in very rapid decline. In 1942, it was estimated that there were 18,000 speakers of it, but it may well be extinct another generation from now (Whinnom 1965)" (Wurm: 1971 pg 1004).
child.publications: 1971. Pidgins, Creoles, and Lingue Franche, Linguistics in Oceania Current Trends in Linguistics (Current Trends in Linguistics), part 2 edn., vol. 8, 999-1021. Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: "Another dialect descended from Ternateño, called Ermitaño. (Whinnom 1965)" (Wurm: 1971 pg 1004)

child.pub-comments: "It is at present spoken and understood by 65,000-70,000 natives" (Wurm: 1971). "Early in the present century, this trade language was adopted as the unofficIal administrative language of Papua and as the language of the Papuan police force, mainly as a result of the encouragement by Sir Hubert Murray, Lieut.-Governor of Papua, who, as had been pointed out in 1.2.6.1, had a strong emotional antipathy to the use of English-based pidgins and did his best to discourage thelf use in Papua (Hall 1966). "Speakers of Police Motu are very unevenly distributed over Papua. The highestpercentage is found in the Central District, followed by coastal and heavily contacted inland areas in the Gulf and Milne Bay Districts" (Wurm: 1971).
child.geography: Territory of Papua of Australian New Guinea
child.publications: 1971. Pidgins, Creoles, and Lingue Franche, Linguistics in Oceania Current Trends in Linguistics (Current Trends in Linguistics), part 2 edn., vol. 8, 999-1021. Paris: Mouton.
